NURS 500: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Identify key theories and models that inform strategies for promoting optimal health outcomes for diverse systems (i.e. individuals, families, communities, and populations).

Use epidemiologic data to evaluate socio-ecological, biological, behavioral and global determinants of health for evidence-based clinical prevention and health promotion interventions for individuals, families, communities, populations and systems.

Use leadership and advocacy strategies to promote equitable, ethical and effective health policy in community, population and global health through inter- and intra-professional approaches to service delivery.

Articulate design principles in health care delivery systems at micro, meso and macro levels that promote consistently safe, high quality and equitable care for diverse systems (i.e. individuals, families, communities and populations).
Evaluate models and leadership principles that facilitate inter-professional quality improvement or safety initiatives.

Apply multiple methods to analyze health and disease across diverse systems (i.e. individuals, families, communities and populations) and develop strategies for quality improvement and health promotion.
NURS 502: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Analyze the physiological mechanisms, control systems, and defense processes that maintain homeostasis.
Apply molecular and cellular concepts to the etiology and pathogenesis of disease processes and syndromes.
Predict from physiological disruptions, the possible clinical features and complications of specific diseases.
Distinguish between adaptive and maladaptive physiological responses to disease processes.
Synthesize the effects of disease that lead to the involvement of multiple systems in either acute or chronic diseases.
NURS 503: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)

Utilize a communication style characterized by sensitive awareness of the diverse needs of individuals, and skill in obtaining and integrating the health history including pertinent contextual information such as age, gender, socioeconomic status, culture, ethnicity, social support, lifestyle, and critical environments.

Appropriately utilize and interpret assessment strategies including clinical interviewing, physical examination techniques, diagnostic procedures, and common laboratory testing in the health assessment of individuals across the lifespan. Interpretation includes recognizing variations of, and deviations from, normal. Utilize appropriate information technology to gather, analyze, and record data.

Demonstrate sound critical thinking, diagnostic reasoning, and clinical decision-making skills in obtaining, interpreting, and integrating health assessments, and recognizing actual and potential problems.
Synthesize case-based knowledge in a comprehensive, developmentally appropriate approach to both focused and health maintenance assessments.
Demonstrate competence in both the written documentation and oral presentation of health assessments. Utilize information technology appropriately in communication and documentation.
NURS 523: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Describe the regulatory and certification guidelines for APRN practice.
Articulate their identity generally as an APRN and identify their area of specialization and population foci specifically.
Demonstrate comprehensive knowledge of health policies that impact advanced nursing practice.
Identify ethical and legal issues encountered by APRNs.
Explore the history and educational pathways for the different APRNs.
Associate the MSN and DNP competencies with role assimilation.
NURS 546: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)

Assess/Manage/Evaluate the care of the essentially uncomplicated woman during pregnancy, in accord with the management process and selected conceptual models of nurse-midwifery/WHNP practice, including screening for selected complications.
Facilitate the development of self-defined family unit or various cultures through education and care which focuses on the parturient couple as collaborators in their health care.
Utilize principles of teaching/learning in preparing individual people/families for childbearing.
Provide sexual information and counseling for pregnant people/families relative to the fulfillment of sexual needs during pregnancy.

Utilize the interdependent professional model of practice which includes consultation, collaboration, and referral with other health team members for the provision of prenatal care of essentially normal people.
Incorporate current findings of nursing and biopsychosocial research into the NMW/FNP management of the antepartum woman and family.
Assess the need for state-of-the-art technology, as indicated to identify risks in the antepartum client.
Describe the embryonic origins, anatomy, and physiology of the male and female reproductive organs and genitalia.
Describe the process of gametogenesis and identify factors that facilitate or impair the process.
Describe normal fetal growth and development.
NURS 561: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Identify and utilize methods of pregnancy confirmation and estimating date of birth.
Recognize and assess for the normal, physiologic and anatomic changes during pregnancy and identify potential departures from normal (examples, vital signs & weight gain).
Identify routine testing (laboratory, genetic, ultrasound) associated with antepartum care in the United States and recognize normal vs. abnormal results.
Assess and identify normal vs. deviations from normal (based on weeks of gestation) for: fundal height, fetal lie, fetal position and fetal heart rate.

Promote family centered antepartum care by utilizing principles of shared decision making and by providing families with essential education during pregnancy (examples, warning s/s, avoiding alcohol/tobacco exposure).
NURS 566: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Analyze and apply essential primary care nursing concepts with a community health nursing framework.

Apply the components of the nurse-midwifery/nurse practitioner management process, i.e., assess, diagnose, manage, and evaluate the health needs of clients who are adolescent through older adult using knowledge, concepts, and models from nurse-midwifery/nurse practitioner practice.
Analyze the role of the nurse practitioner/nurse-midwife in health promotion and management of common, acute, primary care needs including well woman/gynecological care and menâ€™s health.

Utilize relevant evidence based, biopsychosocial, feminist, genetic, cultural theories, and information technology in providing gender and age specific care for individuals from a variety of cultural, socioeconomic status, and racial/ethnic backgrounds with common acute problems and health promotion needs.
Demonstrate the ability to assess, diagnose, manage and evaluate clients with common acute health problems and health promotion/maintenance needs.
Develop collaborative relationships with other health care providers.
Identify and refer clients and/or situations requiring consultation and collaboration.
PHARMACY 620: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Explain the mechanisms of action for major classes of drugs.
Describe the clinical implications of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics to major drug classes and selected drugs.
Distinguish developmental and/or age-related differences in individuals that can affect drug therapy across the lifespan.
Apply principles of pharmacology and pharmacotherapeutics to the selection of drug therapy for patients across the life span.
Use current research data and consensus guidelines to make appropriate evidence-based decisions about drug therapy in patient care.
Identify actual and potential adverse drug reactions associated with major drug classes.
HS 700: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
Recognize the types of numerical data and apply appropriate descriptive statistics to produce summary measures and graphics.
Utilize a statistical software program for basic data analysis.
Select and apply the appropriate statistical technique to test a hypothesis.
Interpret results of statistical techniques covered in class including the assessment of the role of chance.
Be able to evaluate the performance of a diagnostic test.
Identify key applications of statistical techniques to clinical research and practice.
NURS 676: Not aligned with specific course objective(s)
